“Her election is the best way to support the continued strength, security, and reliability of our democracy and economy,” the leaders wrote in a letter shared with CNBC. “With Kamala Harris in the White House, the business community can be confident that it will have a President who wants American industries to thrive.”

Advertisement

The group includes a number of high-profile executives of public companies, including Snap Chairman Michael Lynton and Yelp CEO Jeremy Stoppelman. Other signatories include Chris Larsen, who helped found the blockchain platform Ripple, and Box CEO Aaron Levie.

Advertisement

The majority of the letter’s signatories are former business executives, from former Blackstone CEO Tony James and Lazard CEO Peter Orszag to the many former heads of public companies. Executives who once led Pepsico, Merck, Starbucks, PayPal, and Ford all made the list.

Advertisement

A number of donors aligned with Harris — or the Democratic party more broadly —also signed the letter, including Laurene Powell Jobs, NBA Hall of Famer Magic Johnson, former Walt Disney Studios chairman and Dreamworks CEO Jeffrey Katzenberg, and Facebook co-founder Dustin Moskovitz.

Several of these people have already gone to bat for Harris in the almost two months since she became the defacto Democratic nominee. Cost Plus Drugs Co. founder and Dallas Mavericks minority owner Mark Cuban and Reid Hoffman — both of whom have signed another pledge to support Harris — are signatories, as is IAC Chairman Barry Diller.

Advertisement

“Kamala Harris is pro-business,” Cuban argued earlier this week. “This is Kamala Harris’ campaign, it’s not Joe Biden’s campaign,” later adding that “she’s going center 100%” on business.

Harris’ economic plan includes a push to restore the expanded Child Tax Credit, create a new tax credit that would give low-income or middle-income families with a newborn child $6,000, and slash taxes by up to $1,500 for low-income individuals. She has also pledged to take aim at high prescription drug prices, expensive grocery bills, and Wall Street’s home buying spree.

Advertisement

According to Goldman Sachs analysts, the best outcome of the 2024 presidential election, at least for the economy, would be a Harris win and a Democratic sweep of Congress. The worst scenarios occur when Former President Donald Trump gets back into office and implements tougher controls on immigration and high tariffs on imported goods, the analysts said.

Trump’s economic proposals would also increase the federal deficit by $5.8 trillion over the next decade, almost five times more than Harris’ proposals, which would add $1.2 trillion, according to recent studies from The University of Pennsylvania’s Penn Wharton Budget Model.

article49.headline: Georgia school shooter suspected of killing two teachers was interviewed by FBI
article49.text:
Colin Gray, the father of the teenager accused of killing four people at his Georgia high school faces a 180-year prison sentence for allegedly buying him the gun as a Christmas present.

His 14-year-old son, Colt Gray, faced life in prison, Judge Currie Mingledorff II told Barrow County Court on Friday.

Initially, the teenager was warned that if convicted he could face the death sentence for four counts of felony murder.

However, the judge later corrected his remarks given the minimum age for capital punishment in Georgia is 18, telling the teenager he faced a life sentence.

Colt Gray, who was wearing a green top, sat silently as the judge laid out the potential penalties before later sobbing. He did not enter a plea and was remanded in custody.

Click here to view this content.

Shortly afterwards, he was followed in court by his 54-year-old father, who has been charged with four counts of involuntary manslaughter, two counts of second-degree murder and eight counts of cruelty to children.

Handcuffed and wearing grey-and-white prison fatigues, he rocked in his seat and cried during the brief hearing. Like his son, he did not enter a plea.

Both father and son could face further charges, said Brad Smith, the Barrow County District Attorney, after the hearing.

Click here to view this content.

The victims of the shooting on Wednesday at Apalachee High School in Winder, north-east of Atlanta, were named as Christian Angulo and Mason Schermerhorn, both 14, and maths teachers Richard Aspinwall, 39, and Cristina Irimie, 53.

Victims Christian Angulo, Cristina Irimie, Richard Aspinwall and Mason Schermerhorn are pictured

Nine other people were injured, but authorities said they would recover.

The families of the victims sat in the front row of the court as the proceedings unfolded.

Colin Gray, 54, the father of 14-year-old Colt Gray, has been arrested - Barrow County Sheriff's Office

Mr Gray had been arrested amid reports that the AR-15 style rifle used in the killing may have been bought as a Christmas present.

Colt Gray was interviewed by the Jackson County Sheriff’s Office last year after they were tipped off by the FBI over threats posted on Discord, an online gaming chat site.

Police photos of suspect Colt Gray - Barrow County Sheriff's Office/via Reuters

Warning of a school shooting at “an unidentified location and time”, the threat was on a site called Lanza – the surname of the perpetrator of the 2012 Sandy Hook massacre.

Investigators visited the Grays’ house, where his father said he owned hunting guns, but that his son did not have unsupervised access to the weapons.

The suspect denied making any online threats at the time and said he had deleted his account on the site.

However, NBC reported that Colt’s internet search history showed interest in prior mass school shootings, including the 2018 massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida.

According to witnesses of the shooting, Colt left the classroom at around 9.45am on Wednesday. Lyela Sayarath, a student who was sitting next to the suspect in algebra minutes before, said he showed no signs of what he was about to carry out. When he left, she assumed he was skipping class again.

Text exchange between pupil and parent

Returning with a gun, he was unable to get into his classroom. Instead, he went into a classroom next door and started firing.

The suspect was allegedly bullied by his peers and frequently called “gay”, his father told investigators in a phone call in 2023.

“[They] just ridiculed him day after day after day,” Mr Gray told authorities soon after his son was flagged by the FBI.

He added that his son had been desperate to move schools. “He’s going through a lot… It was very difficult for him to go to school and not get picked on,” he said in a newly revealed transcript.

The suspect’s family leapt to his defence on Thursday after police said he would be charged with the murder of four people as an adult, threatening to go “full throttle” on social media.

However, details of the Gray family’s troubled history have since emerged.

Colt’s mother, Marcee, 43, has a lengthy criminal record, having been arrested for drug, domestic violence and motoring offences. She also served time in jail.

Warrants were issued last November after drugs were found in her car and in April, she was reportedly charged with aggravated battery of a 73-year-old woman.

Click here to view this content.

Kamala Harris, the US vice-president, called the shooting a “senseless tragedy”, while Joe Biden, the president, said he and his wife Jill were “mourning the deaths of those whose lives were cut short”.

Donald Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, wrote on social media: “These cherished children were taken from us far too soon by a sick and deranged monster.”

There have been at least 36 school shootings in the US this year, according to CNN.
